<!--
  Thank you for contributing to Neovim!
  If this is your first time, check out https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-requests-prs
  for our PR guidelines.
-->

## Problem
On Windows, path separators may become inconsistent for various reasons, which makes normalization quite painful(e.g neovim#32590, neovim#28384, neovim#25033, neovim#23639), and makes some issues harder to address(e.g. neovim#8587).

## Solution
We can normalize paths to `/` at the entry boundaries and always use it internally, converting it only for rare cases where `\` is really needed(e.g cmd.exe/bat scripts?)

This is the first PR for neovim#36112, mainly to make sure separators in options and buf names are `/`. Note that `expand/fnamemodify` won't respect shellslash.

comment_data.body: Not sure if there are some programs that also require backslashes when the path contains separatorsâ€”this might be a case for `shellslash`?

The program name format only matters to win32 (well, there could be some edge case where a program inspects its own arg0). I don't think we need to adjust slashes here.

But if we do need to adjust, in all cases we should always use a util function such as `slash_adjust` so that we can easily find all cases.

The logic here might not be very polished, and I haven't fully decided where it should live. For now, `slash_adjust` still respects `shellslash`, but `cmd.exe` requires backslashes when the path contains separatorsâ€”otherwise it may fail with unpredictable errors (e.g. `The syntax of the command is incorrect`). My earlier thought was that if we always normalize to `\` here, we could align with pwsh's behavior, where `cmd` can still be invoked correctly even if the path contains `/`.

If we plan to have `fnamemodify()` return `\` slashes then generally it is useful for tests to reflect that. I.e. in this case keep the old code which asserted `\` (`pathsep`) slashes.

Alternatively, if `fnamemodify()` always returns `/` slashes then we shouldn't need `t.fix_slashes`?

For now, it probably makes sense for `fnamemodify()` to always return `/` slashes.

Also, since this PR was already 40+ files, I planned to handle `expand/fnamemodify/chdir/pwd...` in the second PR. That would require updating more tests and may remove many `fix_slashes`.

comment_regular_data.body:
This looks like a good first step. Ideally shouldn't do too much more than this, assuming CI can be fixed :)

Will plan to merge this quickly after 0.12 release, which is planned for ~1 month from now.

may touch more test files, but changes under `src` shouldn't grow much. Actually, I have tried to reduce the scope in earlier revisions, but it still touches 20+ files, maybe we can see if this can be broken down into smaller PRs after I finishing updateing the tests. :D
That's fine, no need to contort this into weird shapes. Just wanted to set approximate expectations :)
Many of the test changes defeat the entire point of these tests.

> Many of the test changes defeat the entire point of these tests.



Which tests specifically? I don't see much reason to display options or buffer names with platform-specific slashes, so e.g. the changes `test/functional/options/defaults_spec.lua` look ok.

But some things like `fnamemodify()` may be required to return `\` slashes, if they are used by plugins for "normalization". And 'shellslash' is an open question, but might be something we can temporarily break and see what the blast radius is.

> Which tests specifically? 

Mostly the 'shellslash' tests. What even is the point of 'shellslash' if it isn't respected by `expand()` etc.?

> I don't see much reason to display options or buffer names with platform-specific slashes

What do you mean by "display"?

> What do you mean by "display"?

- For options: the actual value (and everywhere it is displayed, e.g. `:set`).
- For buffers: in statusline, and anywhere else where mixed slashes was already possible. 
    - Example: if it's possible for `bufname()` to return mixed slashes, then it's safe for us to always return `/` slashes because there was never a guarantee of only `\` slashes.

### Functions which potentially should respect 'shellslash' (not necessarily required in this PR):

```
exepath
expand
fnamemodify
```

### Documentation

- `vim.uv` will continue to return `\` slashes (we don't control it)

> > What do you mean by "display"?
> 
>   * For options: the actual value (and everywhere it is displayed, e.g. `:set`).
>
>   * For buffers: in statusline, and anywhere else where mixed slashes was already possible.
>       
>     * Example: if it's possible for `bufname()` to return mixed slashes, then it's safe for us to always return `/` slashes because there was never a guarantee of only `\` slashes.

Yes, I think this makes sense. I was talking about the return value of `expand()` etc..
